fragen.frage: Charles Babbage's Analytical Engine is considered the conceptual precursor to the modern computer.
fragen.erklaerung: True! Babbage designed the Analytical Engine in the 19th century with concepts like an arithmetic logic unit, memory, and program control via punched cards, which are still relevant today.

fragen.frage: ENIAC was the first computer to use microprocessors for calculations.
fragen.erklaerung: False — ENIAC (completed in 1946) was one of the first electronic digital computers, but it used vacuum tubes. Microprocessors came much later, starting in the 1970s.

fragen.frage: The invention of the transistor in 1947 enabled the transition from vacuum tubes to smaller, more efficient computers.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The invention of the transistor at Bell Labs revolutionized electronics. It led to the second generation of computers, which were smaller, faster, and more reliable than their vacuum tube predecessors.

fragen.frage: Grace Hopper is credited with popularizing the term 'computer bug' after removing a moth from a relay.
fragen.erklaerung: True! Although the term 'bug' for technical problems already existed, Grace Hopper documented a moth (bug) in a relay of the Mark II computer in 1947, which made the term very famous in the computer field. It was a 'real' bug!

fragen.frage: The World Wide Web was developed in the early 1990s by Bill Gates as part of Microsoft.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The World Wide Web was developed in the late 1980s and early 1990s by Tim Berners-Lee at CERN to facilitate information sharing among researchers. Bill Gates and Microsoft played no direct role in its creation.

fragen.frage: The COBOL programming language was mainly developed for scientific calculations.
fragen.erklaerung: False — As its name suggests, COBOL (Common Business-Oriented Language) was designed for commercial and business applications. FORTRAN was primarily developed for scientific calculations.

fragen.frage: The first microprocessor, the Intel 4004, was introduced in 1971.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The Intel 4004 was the first commercially available microprocessor and ushered in the fourth generation of computers, which enabled the development of PCs.

fragen.frage: The UNIX operating system was originally developed by Microsoft.
fragen.erklaerung: False — UNIX was developed in the late 1960s and early 1970s at AT&T's Bell Labs, primarily by Ken Thompson and Dennis Ritchie. Microsoft was not founded until 1975.

fragen.frage: The Apple I, Apple's first computer, was sold as a complete PC with a case, keyboard, and monitor.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The Apple I was sold in 1976 as a bare circuit board. The case, power supply, keyboard, and monitor had to be added by the buyer. Only the Apple II was a complete PC.

fragen.frage: Ada Lovelace is considered the world's first programmer.
fragen.erklaerung: True! In the mid-19th century, Ada Lovelace wrote an algorithm intended for Charles Babbage's Analytical Engine. She recognized the machine's potential beyond pure calculation.

fragen.frage: ARPANET, the predecessor to the Internet, was mainly developed for commercial purposes.
fragen.erklaerung: False — ARPANET was commissioned by the US Department of Defense (ARPA). It was intended to create a decentralized, fault-tolerant network for military and scientific communication.

fragen.frage: The Turing machine is a practically built computer by Alan Turing.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The Turing machine is a theoretical model of a computer defined by Alan Turing in 1936. It serves as a foundation in theoretical computer science to study the computability of algorithms but was never built as a physical machine.

fragen.frage: The IBM PC from 1981 used a proprietary, closed operating system developed by IBM itself.
fragen.erklaerung: False — IBM chose to license the operating system from a small company called Microsoft. This system became known as PC-DOS (from IBM) and MS-DOS (from Microsoft) and was the cornerstone of Microsoft's later success.

fragen.frage: The 'Integrated Circuit' (IC), which combines multiple transistors on a single chip, is the hallmark of the Third Computer Generation.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The invention of the integrated circuit (IC) by Jack Kilby and Robert Noyce in the late 1950s enabled even smaller and more powerful computers, defining the Third Generation.

fragen.frage: The first computer mouse was developed by Apple in the 1980s for the Macintosh.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The first computer mouse was invented as early as the 1960s by Douglas Engelbart at the Stanford Research Institute (SRI). Apple only later popularized the mouse.

fragen.frage: Linus Torvalds developed both the Linux kernel and the GNU operating system.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Linus Torvalds developed the Linux kernel. The GNU project, which provided many of the basic system tools (like the GCC compiler and the shell), was initiated by Richard Stallman. The combination is often referred to as GNU/Linux.

fragen.frage: Konrad Zuse's Z3 from 1941 is considered the world's first functional, program-controlled digital computer.
fragen.erklaerung: True! Konrad Zuse's Z3 was the first fully automatic, program-controlled, and freely programmable computer that worked with binary floating-point arithmetic.

fragen.frage: The Commodore 64 (C64) was a commercial failure.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The C64, introduced in 1982, is the best-selling home computer of all time. With estimates of 12 to 17 million units sold, it was an enormous commercial success.

fragen.frage: Moore's Law states that CPU performance doubles every year.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Moore's Law (from 1965) states that the number of transistors on an integrated circuit doubles approximately every 18 to 24 months. While this leads to a performance increase, the statement is imprecise.

fragen.frage: The Java programming language was originally developed for interactive television.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The 'Green Project' at Sun Microsystems, from which Java emerged, was originally aimed at developing software for interactive set-top boxes. The project then found a new, much larger purpose with the advent of the WWW.

fragen.frage: The chess computer 'Deep Blue' lost a complete match in 1997 against the reigning world chess champion Garry Kasparov.
fragen.erklaerung: False — IBM's Deep Blue won the match against Kasparov in 1997. It was the first time a computer had defeated a reigning world chess champion under tournament conditions, marking a milestone for artificial intelligence.

fragen.frage: Xerox PARC was a research center that developed many fundamental technologies like the graphical user interface (GUI) and the computer mouse.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The Xerox Palo Alto Research Center (PARC) pioneered many technologies in the 1970s that are taken for granted today, including the GUI, Ethernet, the mouse, and object-oriented programming.

fragen.frage: The Domain Name System (DNS) was introduced to encrypt emails.
fragen.erklaerung: False — DNS was introduced in 1983 to translate human-readable domain names (like 'www.google.com') into machine-readable IP addresses (like '172.217.16.35'). It's essentially the phone book of the Internet.

fragen.frage: The Python programming language is named after the species of snake.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Guido van Rossum, the creator of Python, named the language after the British comedy group 'Monty Python's Flying Circus', of which he was a fan.

fragen.frage: The first commercially successful laptop was the 'Grid Compass' from 1982.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The Grid Compass 1101, designed by Bill Moggridge, is considered one of the first laptops. Its 'clamshell' design became the standard for almost all subsequent laptops. It was even used aboard the Space Shuttle.

fragen.frage: The C programming language was named after B because it was its direct successor.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The C language was developed by Dennis Ritchie at Bell Labs and was heavily influenced by the earlier language B, which was created by Ken Thompson. The name simply follows the alphabet.

fragen.frage: The 'Colossus' computer was built by the British during World War II to break the German Enigma encryption.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Colossus was developed to break the German Lorenz cipher (SZ42), used for communication by the German High Command. The 'Turing-Bombe' was used for the Enigma machine.

fragen.frage: Ethernet was invented at the Xerox PARC research center.
fragen.erklaerung: True! Robert Metcalfe and his team developed Ethernet technology in the early 1970s at Xerox PARC as a method for networking computers in a local area network (LAN).

fragen.frage: The first video game, 'Pong', was released by Nintendo in 1972.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Pong was released by Atari in 1972 and became one of the first commercially successful video games. Nintendo entered the video game market later.

fragen.frage: A 'bit' is the smallest unit of information in computing and can only have the values 0 or 1.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The term 'bit' is an abbreviation for 'binary digit'. All data in a computer is ultimately represented as a sequence of bits.

fragen.frage: Steve Jobs and Steve Wozniak founded Apple Computer to sell software.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The main product was hardware. Steve Wozniak developed the Apple I and Apple II, and the original goal was to sell this computer hardware (first as a kit, then as a finished device).

fragen.frage: The first IBM-compatible PC clone was made by Apple.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Apple always pursued its own, closed architecture. The first IBM-compatible PC was made by Columbia Data Products, but Compaq became known as the first major clone manufacturer with its 1983 model.

fragen.frage: The 'Pascal' language was named after the French mathematician Blaise Pascal.
fragen.erklaerung: True! Niklaus Wirth developed Pascal in the late 1960s as a teaching language and named it in honor of Blaise Pascal, who had invented a mechanical calculator in the 17th century.

fragen.frage: A 'compiler' translates the source code of a program line by line during execution.
fragen.erklaerung: False — That describes an 'interpreter'. A 'compiler' translates the entire program into machine code before execution, which can then be run directly by the processor.

fragen.frage: The Altair 8800 from 1974 is considered the spark that ignited the home computer revolution.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The Altair 8800, sold as a kit, was one of the first affordable personal computers. It inspired a whole generation of enthusiasts, including Paul Allen and Bill Gates, who wrote their BASIC interpreter for it.

fragen.frage: The 'von Neumann architecture' describes a computer design where the operating system is stored on a separate chip.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The von Neumann architecture describes the fundamental design where instructions and data are held in the same memory. This allows a computer to modify its own programs and is the basis of almost all modern computers.

fragen.frage: The first web browser was called 'Internet Explorer'.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The first web browser was developed by Tim Berners-Lee and was called 'WorldWideWeb'. It was later renamed 'Nexus' to avoid confusion with the World Wide Web itself. The first popular graphical browser was 'Mosaic'.

fragen.frage: The first hard drive, the IBM 350, could store several gigabytes of data.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The IBM 350, introduced in 1956, was huge, weighed over a ton, and could only store about 3.75 megabytes. Storage capacity has increased exponentially since then.

fragen.frage: The LISP programming language is known for its strong use in artificial intelligence.
fragen.erklaerung: True! LISP (List Processing), developed in the late 1950s, was one of the first languages for AI research. Its ability to treat code as data (homoiconicity) made it particularly suitable for symbolic computation.

fragen.frage: The 'Y2K problem' referred to a virus that was supposed to infect all computers in the year 2000.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The Y2K problem was a programming bug. Many older systems stored years with only two digits (e.g., '99' for 1999). It was feared that on changing to the year 2000 ('00'), these systems would interpret it as 1900 and crash.

fragen.frage: The company Intel was primarily founded to develop software.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Intel (founded in 1968 by Robert Noyce and Gordon Moore) focused from the beginning on manufacturing semiconductor hardware, especially memory chips and later microprocessors. Its name stands for 'Integrated Electronics'.

fragen.frage: 'Open Source' means that the software is always free of charge.
fragen.erklaerung: False — 'Open Source' means that the source code is freely accessible and can be modified and redistributed. However, companies can still charge money for support, services, or special versions of the software.

fragen.frage: The Cray-1 was a famous supercomputer of the 1970s, known for its unique, C-shaped design.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The Cray-1, designed by Seymour Cray, was not only extremely powerful for its time but also iconic in design. The C-shape helped to minimize cable lengths and thus maximize speed.

fragen.frage: The first email was sent in the 1990s with the advent of the WWW.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The first email was sent as early as 1971 by Ray Tomlinson on the ARPANET. He also introduced the '@' notation to separate the username from the hostname.

fragen.frage: The term 'hacker' originally referred to talented programmers who found creative solutions to technical problems.
fragen.erklaerung: True! In the early days of computer culture at MIT, a 'hack' was a clever technical feat. The negative connotation of criminal intrusion into systems only came later in the media.

fragen.frage: Wi-Fi was developed in the 1970s as a wireless version of ARPANET.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The foundations for Wi-Fi (IEEE 802.11 standards) were only developed and made commercially available in the 1990s. The ALOHAnet in Hawaii in the 70s was an early precursor to wireless networks, but not Wi-Fi.

fragen.frage: The Amiga 500 was a home computer known for its advanced graphics and sound capabilities.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The Amiga 500, released in 1987, was far ahead of its time in terms of multimedia and became particularly popular in the gaming and demoscene.

fragen.frage: The FORTRAN programming language was specifically designed for web development.
fragen.erklaerung: False — FORTRAN (Formula Translation), developed in the 1950s, was the first high-level programming language and was optimized for numerical and scientific calculations. The web did not exist at that time.

fragen.frage: The 'client-server model' describes an architecture where all computers on the network are equal.
fragen.erklaerung: False — That describes a 'peer-to-peer' network. In the client-server model, 'clients' request services from a central 'server' that provides them (e.g., a web server delivering a webpage to a browser).

fragen.frage: The source code for the Windows operating system was released as open source from the beginning.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Windows was and is a proprietary, commercial operating system from Microsoft. Its source code is a closely guarded trade secret, unlike open-source operating systems like Linux.

fragen.frage: Punched tape is a storage medium that was used before the invention of magnetic tapes.
fragen.erklaerung: True! Punched tapes and punched cards were early, widespread data carriers for storing programs and data before magnetic storage media like tapes and later hard disks emerged.

fragen.frage: The first fully functional quantum computer was built by IBM in the 1980s.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Quantum computing is a very current field of research. While the theoretical foundations were laid in the 80s, the first experimental and still very limited quantum computers are a phenomenon of the 21st century.

fragen.frage: A 'daemon' in a Unix system is a malicious program that runs in the background.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A daemon is a system process that runs in the background and provides services (e.g., a web server daemon or a print daemon). Despite its name, the term has no negative meaning.

fragen.frage: The website 'Amazon.com' originally started as an online bookstore.
fragen.erklaerung: True! Jeff Bezos founded Amazon in 1994 as an online marketplace for books. The company only later expanded massively into other product categories and cloud services (AWS).

fragen.frage: The 'GPL' (General Public License) is a software license that allows integrating open-source code into proprietary, closed-source software.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The GPL is a 'copyleft' license. It ensures that any software containing GPL-licensed code must also be released under the GPL. This prevents open code from being incorporated into closed projects.

fragen.frage: The command 'format c:' in MS-DOS was used to clear the screen.
fragen.erklaerung: False — This is an infamous command. 'format c:' irrevocably deleted all data on the hard drive (drive C:). The command to clear the screen was 'cls'.

fragen.frage: RISC (Reduced Instruction Set Computer) is a processor architecture that relies on a small set of simple, fast instructions.
fragen.erklaerung: True! In contrast to CISC (Complex Instruction Set Computer), which have many complex instructions, RISC aims for efficiency through a minimalist instruction set. Modern architectures like ARM are based on this principle.

fragen.frage: The game 'Doom' (1993) is considered technically insignificant for the development of 3D games.
fragen.erklaerung: False — 'Doom' was a technical milestone. It popularized the first-person shooter genre, and its 3D engine was revolutionary in terms of fast textures, varying light levels, and sound design.

fragen.frage: Google was founded in the 1980s as a research project by IBM.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Google originated in 1996 as a research project called 'Backrub' by Larry Page and Sergey Brin, two PhD students at Stanford University. The company Google was founded in 1998.

fragen.frage: A 'kernel' is the central part of an operating system that manages the hardware.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The kernel is the heart of the operating system. It manages CPU time, memory, and peripheral devices, and provides an interface for application programs.

fragen.frage: The BASIC programming language was developed for experienced system programmers.
fragen.erklaerung: False — BASIC (Beginner's All-purpose Symbolic Instruction Code) was designed in the 1960s as a simple, beginner-friendly language to help students get started with programming.

fragen.frage: RAID (Redundant Array of Independent Disks) is a technology for increasing CPU performance.
fragen.erklaerung: False — RAID is a storage technology. It combines multiple physical hard disks into a single logical unit to increase data performance and/or fault tolerance.

fragen.frage: The 'Request for Comments' (RFC) is a documentation format used to standardize Internet technologies.
fragen.erklaerung: True! RFCs are a series of technical and organizational documents about the Internet. Protocols like TCP/IP, HTTP, and SMTP are described in detail in RFCs.

fragen.frage: The Sinclair ZX81 was a home computer known for its huge 1 megabyte of RAM.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The Sinclair ZX81 (1981) was a very cheap entry-level computer and came standard with only 1 kilobyte (KB) of RAM. 1 megabyte was unimaginable for home computers at that time.

fragen.frage: The term 'Cloud Computing' was popularized by Amazon with the launch of AWS in 2006.
fragen.erklaerung: True! Although the concept of distributed computing is older, Amazon Web Services (AWS) commercialized the 'Infrastructure as a Service' (IaaS) model and firmly established the term 'Cloud' in the mainstream.

fragen.frage: A 'stack overflow' is a desirable state that indicates a program is running particularly efficiently.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A 'stack overflow' is a serious program error. It occurs when the call stack overflows, usually due to too many or infinite function calls (recursion). The popular programmer website is named after this error.

fragen.frage: The first laptop with an integrated touchpad was introduced by Apple in the 1990s.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The 1994 PowerBook 500 was the first laptop to use a touchpad instead of a trackball as a mouse replacement, an innovation that quickly became the industry standard.

fragen.frage: The 'C++' programming language was developed as an object-oriented extension of 'C'.
fragen.erklaerung: True! Bjarne Stroustrup developed C++ in the early 1980s by extending the procedural language C with object-oriented programming concepts like classes and objects.

fragen.frage: The USB (Universal Serial Bus) port was developed by IBM in the 1970s.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The USB standard was developed in the mid-1990s by a consortium of seven companies (including Intel and Microsoft) to replace the multitude of different ports for peripheral devices.

fragen.frage: The 'waterfall model' is an agile method of software development.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The waterfall model is the opposite of agile. It is a sequential model where one phase (analysis, design, implementation, etc.) must be fully completed before the next begins. Agile methods are iterative and flexible.

fragen.frage: The first 'smiley' :-) in digital communication was proposed in 1982 by Scott Fahlman.
fragen.erklaerung: True! To distinguish between serious and humorous posts in online discussion forums, computer scientist Scott Fahlman proposed the use of :-) and :-(. This is considered the birth of emoticons.

fragen.frage: The ASCII code is used to convert images and videos into text.
fragen.erklaerung: False — ASCII (American Standard Code for Information Interchange) is a character encoding standard that converts letters, numbers, and special characters into numbers that a computer can process. It is not intended for complex media like images.

fragen.frage: The company 'Oracle' became famous for developing the first graphical web browser.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Oracle is primarily known for its relational database systems and was one of the pioneers in this field. The first popular graphical browser was Mosaic, developed at NCSA.

fragen.frage: The 'BIOS' (Basic Input/Output System) is firmware that is executed first when a PC starts up.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The BIOS is stored on a chip on the motherboard. It tests the hardware (POST) and then loads the operating system from the hard drive or another medium into the main memory.

fragen.frage: 'Spaghetti code' is an appreciative term for particularly elegant and well-structured program code.
fragen.erklaerung: False — 'Spaghetti code' is a derogatory term for unstructured, hard-to-read, and barely maintainable program code, often resulting from excessive use of GOTO statements. Its control flow is as tangled as a plate of spaghetti.

fragen.frage: The 'x86' CPU architecture was originally developed for RISC processors.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The x86 architecture, which began with the Intel 8086, is the epitome of a CISC (Complex Instruction Set Computer) design with a large and complex instruction set.

fragen.frage: The term 'firewall' in network technology is derived from fire protection walls in buildings.
fragen.erklaerung: True! Just as a fire wall is intended to prevent the spread of a fire, a network firewall is intended to stop uncontrolled data traffic between networks (e.g., the Internet and a local network) and only allow authorized traffic to pass.

fragen.frage: The first Palm Pilot from 1996 was shipped with a miniature hard drive.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The Palm Pilot and other early PDAs (Personal Digital Assistants) used volatile memory (RAM) backed up by batteries and had no moving parts like hard drives. This made them robust and power-efficient.

fragen.frage: Bill Gates wrote most of the original MS-DOS operating system himself.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Microsoft bought an existing operating system called QDOS (Quick and Dirty Operating System) from the company Seattle Computer Products and adapted it for IBM. Tim Paterson was the original developer of QDOS.

fragen.frage: The 'TCP/IP' protocol was established by the UN as a global standard for network communication.
fragen.erklaerung: False — TCP/IP became the de facto standard through its use in the ARPANET and later the Internet. It was not developed by an organization like the UN, but by the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF) and its predecessors.

fragen.frage: An 'algorithm' is a precise, step-by-step guide to solving a problem.
fragen.erklaerung: True! An algorithm is like a recipe for a computer. It must be unambiguous, executable, and finite to lead to a result.

fragen.frage: The Perl programming language became popular as a simple scripting language for text processing and report generation.
fragen.erklaerung: True! Larry Wall developed Perl in the late 1980s. It quickly became the 'Swiss Army knife' for system administrators and web developers (through CGI) thanks to its strengths in handling text and regular expressions.

fragen.frage: The 'Apple Lisa' from 1983 was a major commercial success that established the GUI.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Although the Apple Lisa was technologically groundbreaking with its graphical user interface (GUI) and mouse, it was far too expensive at almost $10,000 and thus a commercial flop. Only the cheaper Macintosh a year later popularized the GUI.

fragen.frage: A 'Trojan horse' is a type of malware that self-replicates and spreads across networks.
fragen.erklaerung: False — That describes a 'worm'. A Trojan horse is malware that disguises itself as a useful program to get onto a system. Once executed, it unleashes its malicious effect.

fragen.frage: The first electronic, purely digital calculator was developed in the 1960s.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The 'Cal-Tech' from Texas Instruments (1967) and the HP-9100A (1968) were early examples of electronic calculators that paved the way for the compact devices of the 1970s.

fragen.frage: The 'Harvard architecture' physically separates the memory for instructions and data.
fragen.erklaerung: True! In contrast to the von Neumann architecture, which uses a shared memory, the Harvard architecture uses separate memories. This can increase performance as instructions and data can be accessed simultaneously. Many modern CPUs use a modified form of this.

fragen.frage: The supercomputer 'ASCI Red' was the first computer to exceed the one petaflop performance barrier in the year 2000.
fragen.erklaerung: False — ASCI Red was the first to break the teraflop barrier (10^12 operations per second) in 1996. The petaflop barrier (10^15) was not reached until 2008 by the IBM Roadrunner.

fragen.frage: The 'JavaScript' programming language was developed as a simplified version of 'Java'.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Despite the name, which was chosen for marketing reasons, JavaScript is a language in its own right. It was developed at Netscape for web browser programming and has a different syntax and type system than Java.

fragen.frage: The 'Napster' service in the late 1990s was a centralized peer-to-peer service for exchanging music files.
fragen.erklaerung: True! Although the files were exchanged directly between users (peers), Napster used a central server to manage the list of available files. This central point made the service vulnerable to lawsuits and ultimately led to its shutdown.

fragen.frage: The 'Atari 2600' was a game console that used interchangeable game cartridges.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The Atari 2600 (1977) popularized the concept of the home video game console with interchangeable cartridges, which allowed for a much greater variety of games than devices with built-in games.

fragen.frage: The 'SOLID' principles in software development were formulated by Linus Torvalds.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The SOLID principles of object-oriented programming were largely formulated and popularized by Robert C. Martin ('Uncle Bob').

fragen.frage: A 'GPU' (Graphics Processing Unit) is a specialized processor originally designed only for rendering 3D graphics.
fragen.erklaerung: True! GPUs are optimized for massively parallel data processing, which is essential for calculating 3D graphics. Today, because of this capability, they are also used for many other computationally intensive tasks such as AI training (GPGPU).

fragen.frage: The first social network, 'Facebook', was launched in 2004 by Mark Zuckerberg.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Facebook was not the first social network. Long before it, there were services like 'SixDegrees' (1997), 'Friendster' (2002), and 'MySpace' (2003). However, Facebook became by far the most successful.

fragen.frage: The 'Enigma' machine was used by the Allies in World War II to encrypt their messages.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The Enigma was the encryption machine of the German military. The Allies, especially the British at Bletchley Park, made immense efforts to break the Enigma codes, which significantly influenced the course of the war.

fragen.frage: A 'ROM' (Read-Only Memory) chip loses its data when the power is turned off.
fragen.erklaerung: False — ROM is non-volatile memory. The data is permanently burned in and remains even without power. RAM (Random-Access Memory) is the volatile memory that loses its data.

fragen.frage: The 'ghost in the machine' is a philosophical concept closely associated with Alan Turing's thoughts on artificial intelligence.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The phrase originates from the philosopher Gilbert Ryle, but Turing addressed the idea in his famous 'Turing Test' to investigate the question of whether a machine can think by testing its indistinguishability from human behavior.

fragen.frage: The first 'Personal Digital Assistant' (PDA) was developed by Apple.
fragen.erklaerung: False — One of the first commercially successful PDAs was the 'Psion Organiser' from 1984. Apple only entered the market in 1993 with the 'Newton MessagePad', which was technologically advanced but not very commercially successful.

fragen.frage: SQL (Structured Query Language) is a programming language for creating operating systems.
fragen.erklaerung: False — SQL is a database language specifically designed for communicating with relational databases. It is used to query, insert, update, and delete data.

fragen.frage: The 'Agile Manifesto' of 2001 emphasizes the importance of processes and tools over individuals and interactions.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The Agile Manifesto emphasizes the exact opposite. Its first and most important principle is: 'Individuals and interactions over processes and tools'.

fragen.frage: Virtual Reality (VR) is a concept that was only developed in the 21st century with the advent of powerful graphics cards.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The vision of VR is much older. Ivan Sutherland built the first head-mounted display, the 'Sword of Damocles', as early as the 1960s. However, the technology was extremely cumbersome and expensive at the time.
